ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: a few quizes based on assigned videos, paper presentations, discussions in small groups in breakout rooms, although a lecture the course felt like a seminar

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: A practical understanding of tools like ros, image filtering, and reinforcement learning.  Also a broader understanding of the interactive machines research and general ai communities.
Improved scientific communication skills by presenting on assigned paper topics and on our final projects. Also learned how to use ROS on several homework assignments

It's a mix of control theory, HCI, AI, and machine learning things. The overarching idea is, how do we take input and make sense (no pun intended) out of it? But, frankly, this is one you'll want to read the syllabus class-by-class on, since there's a lot of area to cover.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The course does an excellent job in conveying the desired concepts and giving students practice implementing them.
I thought the class was very well organized - everything was laid out from the beginning, and all of the grading and homework assignments were very clear.

Strengths: Problem sets are hard, but well-written, and I felt like they moved away from the "toy examples" you get in a class like 470 (Artificial Intelligence, which is a prerequisite for this class as I recall) and more into complex but usable ideas. Plus, this class takes you from theory down to implementation pretty nicely.

Weaknesses: It's hard to keep a grip on the big picture. Earlier in the evaluation I felt like I had a hard time answering the "what is this course about?" question, because past the first few weeks, the lectures get a bit disjoint - particularly because about half of them are paper discussions. (Paper discussions are great, but I felt that without more overarching content it was hard to get the most out of them.)

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Lectures as a whole were done very well. The coding done in class was particularly useful for the psets, as were the lecture recordings.

Setting up our own virtual machines was challenging, the cloud resources were underutilized, and the introduction-to-github pset seemed largely unnecessary. In light of this, adding a cloud component to the github pset might be helpful.

I think our small size (~12 people) helped contribute to make it feel more like a lecture/seminar while on zoom. But I really appreciated how the I truly did the most learning while working on homework assignments and the final project.

It's hard to have a good discussion on Zoom. I felt that Professor Vazquez did her best - often splitting into small groups with specific parts of a paper to probe, for instance - but ultimately it's just hard to do. 

On the other hand, I felt that the class staff was very communicative, which was nice in an online course. There's a class Slack, and it was pretty easy to get in touch with a staff member when needed.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Absolutely, more so than any other class that I have taken. The material is fascinating and the skills you acquire are both incredibly practical and cool. The psets themselves have very detailed instructions, telling you exactly how to set everything up. This means that minimal time is wasted on unimportant bugs and your focus can be on learning the concepts.
Yes, it will be a lot of work but you'll get a lot out of it. Marynel is very well organized, gives you lots of feedback, and is there to help when you need it.
Yes, would recommend. It's harder than average, and the content is difficult to grip, but I think it's still worthwhile.
